text: Cars filled with tourists move slowly through the checkpo into Mexico.  On the American side: clean maintained stre
But just across the border: crowds, garbage everywhere, buildings crammed together on pot holed streets.  It seem darker, more dangerous.  Everything has a touch of evil.
A honky tonk street lined with dives.  Neon flickers outs a strip club.  COLLEGE KIDS on Spring Break laugh drunken as they leave the club, one belches loudly. We sneak in while the doors are open.
Almost everyone is American.  Four clean cut young men wa a pair of aging STRIPPERS gyrate on stage.  When the Ugly Stripper dances in front of them, one of them puts a doll in her G-string.
Horman, why are you giving that skank money?
DAVE DELMAR is a massive weight lifter with a troubled childhood which turned him into a bit of a bully.
This is the closest he's been to pussy in months, Del.  Give him a break.
ARTIE HORMAN is the youngest of the group, and the most u of himself.  Maybe still a virgin.  Wears a tourist sombr
Want me to take a picture and send it to your wife?
Lucy would kill me.  Can't even rent R rated movies!
RICK BREEN is the most conservative: already married; dre for church, not strippers.
Only an idiot would get married.
Who you calling an idiot?  I get it at least once a week.

The best looking stripper takes it all off.  Every man in the dive watches her but one: MARTY RACKIN, oldest of the four, keeps his eye on a boot in the back where a slick drug lawyer named VARGAS talks with two MEXICANS in sweat clothes and gold jewelry.
Hey baby!  Come on down!
As the Stripper dances to their side of the room, Vargas gives the Mexicans some hundred dollar bills, and leaves.
Drink up.  It's time to run and gun.
But she's just....
You heard the man: Drink up.
Horman reluctantly ignores the stripper gyrating in front him and finishes his beer.  The four follow Vargas out.

Rackin doesn't lose sight of Vargas.  The four cross the street to a parked car, and Delmar pops open the trunk. Vargas is a block away.  He stops at a door, makes sure n one is watching him, then gives a secret knock.  The door opens and Vargas enters the building.
Got him?
Yeah.  Next block.  Sixth door down.
Rackin watches the door close, then takes the flack jacke Delmar hands him.  All four men put on jackets.  Camoufla grease paint is passed around, and they paint their faces
Horman wants to know if we can go back and see the stripper afterwards.
Sorry, Artie.
Delmar hands each of the men a HUGE military style M249 S machine gun.  Horman also takes a combat shotgun. Armed for a small war, they close the car trunk.
Ready to rumble?

Horman sails the sombrero across the street.  They slap h with each other.  Rackin oozes wild charisma. His team wo follow him to hell and come back with the Devil on his or The four walk down the street like The Wild Bunch.
At the doorway, Breen eases a fiber optic strand quietly under the door.  From this point on, the team uses milita hand signals to communicate.
A distorted look at the foyer beyond the door.            Two GUARDS armed with Uzis smoke cigarettes.

Breen pulls out the strand and signals that there are two guards, armed, and points to where they are standing. The others nod. The door of the next building opens and a TEN YEAR OLD BO steps out...  Sees the armed men and is frightened. Breen puts a finger to his lips, smiles and gestures for Boy to go back inside.  The Boy returns to safety indoors Rackin gives final hand signal instructions to the team. Then they break open the door.

The door splinters inwards, and the two GUARDS quickly br up their Uzis.  Rackin shoots the one of the left before can get off a shot.  Breen takes out the one on the right seconds before he fires at Delmar. Rackin gestures for Delmar to guard the door, while Breen and Horman will use two-by-two cover formation to climb t stairs.  Rackin will check out the downstairs rooms. Rackin doesn't get far before gunfire erupts. A pair of massive MEXICANs in sweats, armed with Uzis, po from the top of the staircase and opens fire down at Bree and Horman.
Two of them!  On the stairs!

Breen and Horman back down the stairs and take cover as bullets turn steps into sawdust. Rackin turns to help them, when he hears a noise, spins a fires down the hallway... Blasting GUARD #3 off his feet before he gets all the way out the door.   Rackin gives it a beat to see if the Guar has any friends, but no one comes.  He goes to help... Breen covers Horman as he rolls from behind cover and fir thew shotgun up at the two Mexicans. MEXICAN #2 comes rolling down the stairs, dead.
They got Manny!

Breen runs up the stairs, taking them two at a time, M249 SAW machinegun ready. Mexican #1 swings out and fires a burst, sending Breen ba a couple of steps. When Mexican #1 starts coming down the stairs, Breen send burst of gunfire to chase him up. For a moment, it's like an Errol Flynn/Basil Rathbone sta sword fight... but with machineguns.  Breen forcing the Mexican up a few steps, then the Mexican forcing him back Then Breen fakes right, moves left, and blasts Mexican #1 right off his feet.  When Breen gets to the top of the st he gestures for Rackin and Horman that it's clear.

head_text.subj: AT THE TOP OF THE STAIRS

text: A hallway and two doors.  Rackin gestures for Horman to c while Breen uses the fiber optic strand. Breen pushes the strand under the first door.
The distorted view of the room... Empty.

head_text.subj: AT THE TOP OF THE STAIRS

text: Breen pulls out the strand and shakes his head. They creep to the next doorway, Breen sticks the strand i

A distorted view of a drug lab. RAY VARGAS, the sleazy American drug lawyer, has a briefc full of money.  Three DRUG DEALERS are opposite a table stacked with bags of black tar heroin.  A WOMAN hides in back of the room.  GUARD #4 stands near the door, gun rea to fire at the first one through.

head_text.subj: AT THE TOP OF THE STAIRS

text: Breen pulls out the strand and relays the information. Rackin nods, and gestures instructions.  Horman will lay the floor with the shotgun aimed up.  Breen will take one side of the door and Rackin the other.  Nods.

Vargas looks around nervously.  Guard #4 keeps his gun re THE DOOR SPLINTERS OPEN and Guard #4 fires... but there's one standing in the doorway.  A moment of confusion. By the time Guard #4 looks down, it's too late.  Horman B him right off his feet. Rackin and Breen swing into the room, guns ready.
Hands!  Everybody!  Hands!
Get 'em up!
Everyone raises their hands.  DRUG DEALER #3 keeps his ha chest level... under his lapel is a gun in a shoulder rig Rackin yells down to Delmar.
Clear.
Copy that.
Rackin gestures for the Woman to come out from her hiding place, then looks over the bags of heroin.
Look, there's been a mistake...
There has?
Yes.  I'm an American citizen.  I know you're just doing your job, but I don't belong here.
Buying heroin?
See, I asked at a bar where I could find some whores, and they must have misunderstood me...
Why don't you put your hands against the wall.  You know the position.
Hands against the wall!
Everyone assumes the position.  Vargas still pleads with Rackin.  Trying not to get busted.
We're on the same side.  I'm a lawyer. I have ID.... in my wallet.
Check his wallet.
That's when Drug Dealer #3 goes for his gun!
But finds an empty holster.  Rackin laughs, holds up the missing gun as if it's part of a magic trick.
Looking for this?  Don't you know I'm magic?
Rackin does a few impressive gun tricks, then turns his h and the gun is GONE... disappeared.  Great close up magic
I'm the magic man.
Horman pulls Vargas' wallet, opens it.  Money, credit car and a California Drivers License.
He's American.  Ray Vargas.  From San Diego.  Visa,  American Express...
See?  This is a mistake.  You D.E.A. guys are doing a great job with the war on drugs, but...
We're not with the D.E.A.
F.B.I.?  D.E.A.?  We're all Americans. You can let me go...

Rackin smiles at Vargas, then nods to Breen. Breen opens fire, St. Valentine's Day Massacre style.  Al four men and the woman are shot to pieces. Horman pulls the money from Vargas' wallet, pockets it.
(laughs) He thought we were with the FBI.
The others laugh as they gather up the briefcase full of money and the bags of black tar heroin, and vacate the ro
At the bottom of the stairs, Rackin nods at Delmar.
What'd we get?
Few hundred thousand and a lot of heroin.  Not that Mexican brown shit, either... Black tar.  Mucho salable.
The four men leave the building.
The Ten Year Old Boy hides in a doorway as the four men w past.  While watching them, he notices a tattoo on Delmar arm.  The U.S. Marine Corps Symbol.
The U.S. Marine Corps symbol on the gate of Camp Richards A beautiful spring day.  Marine Corps Band marching music the background. A title is supered with the camp name and location.

A line of MARINES marches past GENERAL ANTHONY NEWHOUSE.  Newhouse is a rugged, war hardened, leader.  More John Wa than Jack Webb, he weighs exactly what he weighed when he joined the Marines twenty five years ago. Next to General Newhouse is his aide, Lt. PETER VEILLERS. Veillers has spent too much time behind a desk filling ou paper work.  He looks too soft for combat. Each Marine salutes Newhouse as he passes. Gunnery Sergeant Martin L. RACKIN salutes as he passes, followed by Sgt. Breen, Corporal Horman, and Sgt. Delmar. When Delmar salutes, we see the tattoo on his arm again. The cold blooded killers who knocked off Vargas and the D Dealers are United States Marines!

War.  A Marine Recon Team trapped behind enemy lines, as bullets spray around them.  Explosions illuminate the car Twisted metal.  Four dead Marines. Gunnery Sergeant RONALD L. MURPHY yells into a radio.
Base.  This is Force Recon Five.  We are under heavy fire, I repeat, heavy fire.  Request immediate extraction.

Another explosion shows Sgt. TED NEWHOUSE, early 20s and scared to death.  His name printed on his camouflage.  A bloody rag has stopped the bleeding from the bullet wound his leg.  Gripping Murphy's free hand.
Get me out of here, Murphy...
Base.  This is Force Recon Five, do you copy?
Copy, Recon Five.  Give me your Team Leader...
Team Leader is dead.  Primary Radio is dead.  Second Radio and Tail-end Charlie are dead.  This is the Point Man, Ron Murphy... Requesting immediate extraction.  Code word is Switchblades.
Give me the Assistant Team Leader.
Assistant Team Leader is wounded.  We need air extraction NOW.
Unable to extract from your co-ords.
I have a wounded man....
Chopper is waiting at extraction point alpha...
A huge explosion sends debris over Murphy and Ted.  When Murphy tries the radio again, he only gets static.
Base?  Base?
Murphy lowers the mike, turns to Ted.
I can't carry you.  You'll have to wait here.
Come on, Murph... Don't leave.
Just hang on, Ted.  I'll come back with help.
Don't leave me Murph... Please don't leave me here to die...
Ted reaches his hand out, as Murphy scrambles away.  Bull and explosions shattering the night.
Murphy!  Murphy!
Murphy comes out of the nightmare... hears his name echoi
Murphy?
On a chain around his neck: Three dog tags.  Two in perfe condition with his name.  The third, brown with corrosion (blood?), with the name EDWARD NEWHOUSE.
The Marine Corps main base. A title is supered with camp name and location.

General JOHN LATIMER is the top man in the Marine Corps.  Rugged and powerful, he earned his respect the old fashio way: He was a war hero. Latimer lets the JAILER lead him down the unfamiliar hall to a dark cell.
Murphy in there?
The Jailer nods, unlock the door... Waits for instruction
You can go.
The Jailer salutes, leaves.  Latimer enters the cell.
Murphy looks up at Latimer, but doesn't salute.
What do you want?
You're Gunnery Sergeant Ronald L. Murphy?
That's right.  Here to personally kick me out, General?  I'm honored.  I don't even think Riddick Bowe got this kind of service.
You used to be the best Recon man there was...
Used to be.
They say you punched an officer.
I was drunk.
Being drunk isn't an excuse, it's another offense.
This is what?  Your fifth?  Sixth offense?
What's your point?
Ever since Desert Storm you've been on the fast track to Court Martial.  One fight after another.
I swear: That was the last.
You're right.  Your hearing is scheduled for tomorrow.  You'll probably do ten years in federal lock up before you're dishonorably discharged.
Murphy looks down at his unpolished shoes.
You're here to see me off.
I'm here to offer you a deal.
Murphy looks up.
Two weeks ago, an American lawyer named Raymond Vargas and seven Mexican citizens were murdered in Tiajuna.  Shot more than a dozen times.  Execution style.
So?
The killers left behind bullets and brass.  Because one of the victims was an American, the Tiajuna Police worked overtime on the case, came up with some surprising results.
Suicide?
The weapons were U.S. Marine Corps issue.  5.56mm SAW machine guns.
Stolen?
Maybe.  A ten year old who witnessed the murders said the killers were soldiers.  One of them had a Marine Corps tattoo on his arm.
Shit.

After last year's hazing scandals, we want to nip this one in the bud.  Camp Richards is just across the border from Tiajuna.  We're afraid that someone may be selling, stealing, or trading Marine issue ordnance to drug dealers.
What does this have to do with me?
Recon is your specialty.  Sneaking behind enemy lines and returning with troop and target information.
That was in Storm... Years ago.
We want you to go undercover at Camp Richards.  Find out how these weapons are getting off the base.  The names of any personal involved.
Newhouse still runs that base.
Correct.  General Newhouse is in charge of Camp Richards.
Can't do it.
You can't run from the man forever, Murphy.
I killed his son.
Murphy's intensity is frightening... But Latimer responds only with a nod.  He locks eyes with Murphy.
There is no room in this Marine Corps for criminals and hooligans, Sgt. Murphy.  No room for men like you. (beat) But if you do your job right... find those responsible for these weapons
ending up in the wrong hands... You will have transformed yourself from one of them, to one of us.
Yes, sir.

A Marine Corps jeep rolls up to the checkpoint.  The DRIV shows his paperwork to the OFFICER at the gate. The Officer looks over the paperwork, hands it back to th Driver, looks at Murphy in the passenger seat.
What have we here?
Corporal Ronald L. Murphy.  Transfer from Fort Lejuene, sir.
Murphy, cleaned up but minus some uniform stripes, hands Officer his paperwork. The Officer looks it over, nods.
Says here you used to be a Gunny.  Got busted down a few grades.
Yes, sir.
The Officer turns to the Driver.
Show CORPORAL Murphy to his quarters. (to Murphy) Then the General wants to see you.
Yes, sir.
Murphy salutes, unhappy, and the jeep drives onto the bas The Officer at the Gate watches it drive away.
Lt. VEILLERS sits guard in the anteroom to General Newhou office.  The ultimate weaselly male secretary.
Corporal Murphy to see General Newhouse.
Veillers inspects Murphy like a slab of meat.  An undercu of homosexuality from Veillers.
Murphy?  Hmmmm.
Veillers looks through the files on his desk, taking enou time to show Murphy who is in charge.
Yes.  I believe the General is expecting you. (to intercom) Corporal Murphy's here.
Veillers buzzes Murphy in to General Newhouse's office.
Murphy salutes.  Newhouse has Murphy's file open on his d and every word he speaks is barbed.
Corporal Ronald L. Murphy, sir.
Corporal.  Welcome to Camp Richards.  We hope you'll do better here than you did at Camp Lejuene.
Yes, sir.
You know, Murphy, I was against your transfer here.  But General Latimer explained his reasoning in detail.
Murphy wonders how much Newhouse was told of his mission.
What do you think of his decision?
I'm just here to follow orders, sir.
Excellent.  You seem to have had some difficulties with that in the past. (leafs through file) A discipline problem.  They thought I might be able to straighten you out.
Murphy realizes Newhouse knows nothing of his mission.
Yes, sir.
Unlike General Latimer, I don't believe in second chances.  I can't forgive past mistakes. (leafs through file) And you've made a lot of them.
Newhouse keeps the file open to the Recon incident where son was killed.

Make even the smallest mistake here, and it will be my pleasure to Court Martial you and cart you off to a military prison for the rest of your shitty little life. (beat) Do you understand me, Murphy?
Yes, sir.
You're dismissed.
Murphy salutes and leaves.  Breaking the rules to investi the missing guns may land him in jail for ever.
Rackin, Breen, Delmar, and Horman watch as Murphy leaves General's Office Building.
Kind of old for a Corporal.
The Gate Officer said Newhouse put him on the top of the shit list.
Interesting.
The watch Murphy cross the base to the barracks buildings
Corporal Horman.  Find out everything you can about our new man.
Yes, sir.
Horman heads to the General's Office, the others watch Mu enter his barracks.

No one talks to Murphy as he opens his duffel bag and unp He has his bunk, his locker... his part of the world. No friends, no real home. The other MARINES keep their distance.  No one talks to h welcomes him, or acknowledges him. Murphy's first day on the base, he's already a pariah. When no one is looking, he takes a pack containing a mini camera, lock pick equipment, burglar tools and hides it u his matress.

Murphy waits at the counter for Sgt. TOM FULLER, the supp sergeant for the base. While Murphy waits, he notes the location of the computer and ledgers, where information on the stolen guns might b found.   One of the ledgers is on the counter. Fuller finishes and does his best Gomer Pile imitation.
Supplies, Supplies.  What can I get for you, Corporal?
Bedding supplies.
Fuller goes to grab the basic bedding kit: Blanket, sheet pillow, etc.  Murphy tries to sneak a peek into the ledge Looking for guns and ammo.  Almost gets caught.
Where you from?
Camp Lejuene.  How often do they do inventory around here?
Why?  Looking for a five finger discount?  Wonder how long before you'll be caught?
Wondering if I order a new pair of boots how long it'll take you to get them.
Seven working days.
So you order, what?  Once a week?
Yeah.  Lotta questions for a transfer.
Just trying to learn my way around.
What size?
What?
Boots.  You need new boots, right?  We may have them in stock...
Eleven and a half.
Fuller shakes his head. Murphy grabs the sheets, starts o
Just a minute.
When Murphy turns, Fuller is examining the ledger.
What?
Your name.  Rank.  Military ID number or Social Security number.
For Fuller's report?  Murphy hesitates.
For the bed kit.
Right.
Murphy sets everything down, fills the information out in the ledger, and signs for the bed kit.
The MARINES get ready for hand to hand combat practice.  Murphy stands alone. Across the room, Horman whispers to Rackin, who eats an a
Good work.
Rackin and the team wander over to where Murphy loosens u
Kind of old for a Corporal.
I used to be a Gunny.
What'd they bust you down for?
Fighting.
You good at fighting?
I'm good at everything.
(laughs) Think you could take on Sgt. Breen, here?
Murphy looks over Breen.  They're about the same size, sh be an even fight.
Sure.
Ten bucks for every minute you stay off the mat.
Make it twenty.
Twenty....
GENERAL NEWHOUSE claps for attention.

Your rifle may be your best friend, but you are not useless without it.  Hand to hand combat skills are your last line of defense, your only chance at survival in the field if a mission blows up in your face.
Murphy looks down, trying to forget his past.
You know the moves, let's see what you can do in a practice session.  Remember, in the field, you'll be fighting for your life. (beat) Pair up on the mats, I'll blow the whistle to start.
Breen and Murphy pair up. But right before General Newhouse blows the whistle, the massive DELMAR taps Breen on the shoulder.
Mind if I cut in?

Breen steps aside, and Murphy gets a less than a second t size up his new opponent before the whistle blows. Rackin takes a bit of his apple, watching from the sideli Delmar gets the first strike, almost knocking Murphy off feet.   But waking him up. Murphy goes into action, using judo, akido, and street fighting skills to evade Delmar's next hits and get in a of his own.
You're not bad.
The bigger they are...
The harder they hit.

Delmar SLAMS Murphy with a solid punch, sending him to th floor.  But Murphy hits the mats and twists, kicking Delm legs out from under him.  Delmar falls HARD. Murphy rolls over on him, pinning him to the mat.
You hit hard, but you don't hit smart.

Rackin watches the fight closely from the side lines. Delmar headbutts Murphy and flips him off. The two fight on the ground, until Murphy flips back onto his feet and kicks at Delmar. Delmar is taking a beating.  It's obvious that Murphy is better fighter.  But Delmar has the weight.
You want to play?
When Murphy chops at Delmar, the brute plucks his hand fr the air and THROWS Murphy over his shoulder to the mat. Then pounces on him. Murphy rolls away, but Delmar grabs him and pulls him bac
I play for keeps...

Murphy can't get away.  Delmar puts his elbow to Murphy's throat and applies pressure.... strangling him. It has become a fight to the death!  Murphy scrambles, tr to get the brute's elbow off his throat.  He's turning bl Then the whistle blows, and Delmar lets up. Murphy gasps for breath while Delmar pops to his feet.  T Delmar reaches down and helps Murphy up.
You're pretty good.
Rackin gets Delmar's attention, gestures to bring Murphy.
Handled yourself pretty well.
You said something about some money.
Rackin tosses his apple core, wipes his hand, offers it.
Marty Rackin.  That's Breen, Horman.  You've already met Delmar.
Who pays me?
You don't take shit from anyone.  I like that. (beat) I'll get you a weekend pass on Friday.
And my twenty five bucks?
The man's obsessed with money.
Rackin twists his hand and a twenty dollar bill magically appears in it.  He hands it to Murphy.
Hell of a trick.
I've got a million of them.
Rackin and his team leave Murphy in the Mat room.
Quiet on the base.   A few MARINES patrol the darkness.

A room full of sleeping Marines.  It's long past lights o Murphy seems to be asleep like the others.  His eyes open He carefully sneaks out of bed and pulls on his pants. While grabbing his boots, he makes a noise.

The MARINE sleeping on the next bunk rolls over.  Waking Murphy stays still for a moment, then continues dressing. He pulls the pack of burglar equipment from under his bed and sneaks past the sleeping Marines to the door.

Murphy stays close to the walls as he sneaks across the b to the Supply Building. When he rounds the corner of a building, he almost runs i a two man PATROL making their rounds. Not enough time to retreat, Murphy ducks into a dark door The Patrol continues towards him.
Check the doors.

Patrolman #2 shines his flashlight on the door across fro Murphy.  He palms the knob.  Locked. Murphy sees the flashlight turning his way and hits the d Laying on the ground near the door. Patrolman #2's flashlight his the empty doorway.   Murphy has to hold his breath as Patrolman #2 stands only inches away and checks the door knob.
All locked?
Patrolman #2 nods.  The Patrol rounds the corner. Murphy gets out of the dirt and continues sneaking across the base to the Supply Building.
Murphy uses the lock picks from his kit to get in.
Murphy pushes the door closed and sneaks behind the count A pencil flash from the kit helps him find his way to the computer in the back of the office.

Murphy turns off the flash and boots the computer. The room is suddenly bathed in blue light from the monito Murphy ducks.  Will the light attract the Patrolmen? Time passes.  It's safe.  Murphy begins typing commands i the computer.  Gets a menu of inventories.  Most recent..
(sotto) A week ago.

Calls up the inventory. The screen shows BLANKETS, how many before, how many issu how many at inventory, how many Lost, Damaged, Destroyed. He scrolls down the list, finding the list of weapons... A light flashes through the window from outside!  A Patro Murphy hides behind the counter.
The two man Patrol shines their flashlight into the doorw
Check the door.
Patrolman #2 starts towards the door.
Through the window, Murphy can see Patrolman #2 coming... He has left the door unlocked! Murphy scrambles to the door, flicking the lock just as..
Patrolman #2 tries the door.  Locked.  He moves on.
When they've gone, Murphy sneaks back to the computer. M249 SAW Machineguns..... The number at the beginning and end of the inventory are the same.  None are lost or dama
Unaccounted for: 0 Murphy checks ALL of the guns.... All are accounted for. LIVE AMMO shows many rounds issued for training exercises Fuller has signed for most of them personally.

Murphy sneaks out of the building, picks the door locked. When he starts sneaking back to the barracks, he hears a noise.  Talking.  A flashlight.  The Patrol has returned! Murphy hides in the shadows on the far side of the buildi
I can't believe Fuller left the damned computer on...
Patrolman #1 flashes his light inside the Supply Building The computer is off, the Supply Building completely dark.
I must be losing my mind.  Come on.

The Patrol leaves the area. Murphy comes out of the shadows, then notices a small sup shack with dozens of locks and chains protecting it. His pen light illuminates the 'address': BUILDING 48-H. Murphy shuts off his flash and sneaks back to the barrack
Murphy puts his burglar kit back under the matress, takes off his boots and pants, and climbs into bed.
Reveille sounds.  Marines go through their morning routin
Murphy makes sure no one is looking, dials a number.
General Latimer, this isn't a secure phone.  I'm going to make it fast.  There was an inventory last week.  No weapons missing, but they may have cooked the books. (beat) Yes, sir.
Murphy hangs up and falls in for breakfast. From across the Parade Grounds Sgt. Breen watches Murphy. Wondering what the phone call was about.
Murphy, Rackin and the rest of the Marines on base are dr in full camouflage, helmets, packs, and rifles.
Today we'll be running the "Quigley" Course.  This is a hard-ass course.  Has nothing to do with that dopey Tom Sellack movie.  This course is for real Marines.
Breen continues to study Murphy.
You will start in this muddy ditch. You will crawl down the ditch, your point man checking ahead of him for poisonous snakes.
Poisonous snakes?
That's right, Corporal Horman. (beat) At the end of the ditch you will run five miles through the woods, climb a forty percent grade, then slide down the other side.
Murphy has been through all of this before... and worse i Desert Storm.  He and Rackin seem relaxed.
Then you will crawl along a length of razor wire while Lieutenant Veillers fires a 50 caliber machinegun over
your heads.  Because today is Friday, we will be firing blanks.
Horman looks slightly relieved.
When you hear the pistol, start moving.
Newhouse raises his gun and fires. Murphy, Rackin, and the Marines hit the dirt, crawling th the muddy ditch, holding their guns up out of the water.
Go! Go! Go! Go! Go!

The muddy Marines run through the woods, rifles ready for action.  They climb the grade, and slide down the other s Horman gets in trouble, and Breen has to help him out. Murphy and Rackin run with ease.  Next to each other.  Al like a team.  Both men are naturals.
At the razor wire, a dozen Marines hit the dirt and crawl along the path as Sgt. Fuller fires a machinegun overhead
Go!  Go!  Go!  Go!  Go!
Rackin lets Murphy crawl ahead alone.  Murphy crawls alon the wire, keeping his head down.  The machinegun firing.. Send dirt spraying all around Murphy. They are using live rounds.
Shit!

Bullets flying right overhead, like that night in Iraq. FLASH CUT:  Murphy in Iraq.  Bullets and explosions.  Han on to Ted's hand. Murphy snaps out of it and uses all of his combat trainin to stay low and avoid the machinegun fire.  He crawls to safety, moves to his feet, and spits dirt from his mouth.
Rackin gives Sgt. Fuller a glance as he crawls through th fire zone.  No bullets come anywhere near him. Rackin comes to his feet next to Murphy.
He's using live ammo.
Must be a mistake.
I could have been killed.
Rackin shrugs, makes a gate pass appear in his hand: magi
Then you could probably use a drink.
He hands the pass to Murphy, who smiles at it.
McBain's is a Marine hangout, the way McP's in Coranado i Navy SEAL Team hangout.  Flashing neon and loud music.
Cheap pitchers of beer, and lots of attractive women. Murphy comes in with Rackin and his team.  Everyone in th joint greets Rackin as if he's their king.
Marty!  It's the magic man!  Marty!
Rackin high fives some of the Marines on his way to be ba Delmar lags behind to talk to some of them.  Whispered conversations.  Money changes hands.  Gambling?
Quite a fan club.
They love the magic man.  I make all their problems disappear... With a pitcher of beer.
Rackin makes a $5 bill appear and pays for the pitcher.
How long you been in the Corps?
Since Storm.  I re-upped.
Jeeze, you don't want to go home?
Couldn't wait to leave.

I carried him as long as I could.  He was already dead when I finally laid him down.
Murphy pulls out his dog tags, takes off Ted Newhouse's tarnished tag and hands it to Newhouse.
Now will you help me?  Will you listen to me?
Newhouse looks at the dog tag in his hand.  His son's.
There's an organized gang on the base. Run by Gunnery Sergeant Marty Rackin.  They're using equipment, weapons, and supplies to take over the drug business on the West Coast.
Bullshit.
I went along on one of their Midnight Raids.  Civilians were killed, sir.

I can't believe this could happen here.  The Marine Corps is based on a chain of command.  Respect for superior officers.  Following orders. (beat) How could one man disobey so many orders that it came to this?
I don't know, sir.
Rackin stands in the doorway, aiming his SAW at Murphy.
We gave him a chance, but he's just not a good soldier.  Won't do what he's told.
Delmar enters and steps up to Murphy, nudging the back of his head with his pistol.
Drop it, jackass.
Murphy drops his gun.
Sergeant Delmar, make sure Corporal Murphy is involved in a training accident.  A fatal one.
Yes, sir.

Delmar nudges Murphy out the door.  To his death. Newhouse looks from the corroded dog tag up to Rackin.  H tone with Rackin is paternal, as if Rackin had been caugh TPing the neighbor's house... not trying to kill Murphy.
Marty, how could you let it go this far?  It's completely out of control.
I'm sorry, sir.  I thought I could trust him.  But he ended up being a rat.  You know how much I hate rats.
The base is on full alert.  Everyone heard the shooting. (beat) There'll probably be an investigation.
You could say we were running a night training exercise...
(stern) You should have come to me first.
Rackin nods.  General Newhouse may want to punish him.
I'm sorry, sir.  It won't happen again.
Newhouse nods, looks back down at the dog tag.
The Quigley Course. Delmar prods Murphy out to the middle of the woods near t muddy ditch with the barrel of his gun.
This is a good place.
Delmar presses the gun into the back of Murphy's head.
Hey.  Sorry it didn't work out.
Delmar's finger tightens on the trigger.
Murphy ducks, spins and knocks the gun from Delmar's hand
You son of a bitch.  Could have been painless.  Could have been easy.  But you want to do it the hard way.

Murphy prepares to fight the brute. It's a battle of the titans. A true fight to the death. Delmar pulls out a HUGE jungle knife and attacks before M can get to his own knife. DELMAR AND MURPHY fight hand to knife. The blade striking out again and again at Murphy.         Murphy evades it and lands a punch on Delmar's face.
This is kind of fun, isn't it?
Delmar stabs down at Murphy's neck. Murphy has no choice but to GRAB THE KNIFE BLADE.
AGHHH!
The blade cuts into his fingers and palm as Murphy pushes away, then rolls away.  Delmar gets ready to strike again SPINNING, Murphy kicks the knife out of Delmar's hands.
THE KNIFE sticks into a nearby tree.
Now it's even.

Delmar attacks, fighting Murphy hand to hand.  The two ki parry, and thrust.  Feet and hands slamming into each oth chest with enough force to send them sprawling. Murphy hits the ground, rolls to his feet to attack. Delmar is ready, blocks the punch. He slams Murphy with his elbow.  HARD. Murphy almost goes down.
Murphy lands three hits in a row, forcing Delmar backward

Delmar laughs it off and charges. He slams against Murphy and both go hurling backwards to a tree. Delmar slams Murphy's head repeatedly against the tree. Murphy reaches up... fingers touching the knife.  He pull it out of the tree and STABS at Delmar. Delmar lets go of Murphy and pulls the knife from his che
Not enough force.  You must have missed the day we learned how to use a knife.
He holds it up and SNAPS it in half, throwing the pieces away.  Then he charges Murphy again. Murphy steps away from the tree at the last moment, and D SLAMS into it.  Falls to the ground.
You didn't miss the tree.
Murphy moves in for the kill, but Delmar rolls away. Delmar rolls onto his feet, and gestures for Murphy to co forward and fight.
Ready to give up?  I'll kill you quickly.  Put you out of our misery.
No thanks.

Murphy moves in and they resume their fight. Kicking, chopping, hitting, flipping, rolling, and punchi Murphy continues landing hits, but Delmar won't go down. DELMAR AND MURPHY continue fighting around the Quigley Co each one landing impressive hits on the other. But Delmar doesn't feel the hits like Murphy.  Murphy is taking a beating.
There's no way you can win.
If I give up, there's no way I win.
Murphy lands three good hits in a row, sending Delmar bac
Delmar hits a tree, then bounces back to his feet.
It's been fun, but now it's over.
Delmar gets ready to kill Murphy with a final attack. Murphy isn't sure he can take another full attack.

Delmar slams into Murphy and the two fight. Delmar keeps forcing Murphy towards the razor wire. Murphy finds himself pushes back to the edge of the wire. Back hitting the barbs with no place else to go. Murphy takes hit after hit.  He finally spins, landing tw good hits on Delmar that force the brute against the wire Delmar gets tangled in the razor wire.  The more he tries dig out of it, the more it digs into him.
You can't fight it and win.

Delmar roars to his feet, dragging a few yards of coiled razor wire behind him, and CHARGES AT MURPHY! If Murphy gets tangles in the razor wire, it's over. Murphy goes for his gun... But the flap is snapped.  He scrambles backwards, trying to free his weapon. Trips over a log and goes down. Delmar The Razor Man rushes at him. Murphy fumbles with his gun.  Delmar getting closer.  He gets the gun out.  Gets it up.  Delmar ON TOP OF HIM.

Blasts Delmar right off his feet.  The brute falls dead o inches away from tangling up Murphy. Murphy stops to take a breath. Delmar GRABS HIS LEG.  Start pulling himself closer! Murphy gives him a kick in the face, then scrambles away. Delmar is too tangled to crawl, and dies. Murphy holsters his gun and runs.
Murphy runs across the Parade Grounds to the phone booth.
Murphy gets to the phone, closes the door behind him.  Sa He digs in his pocket for change. Nothing.
Shit.
Picks up the phone and hits "0".
Operator, I'd like to make a collect call to...
The phone booth door pops open and a pair of MARINES grab him and yank him out.  One is the Gate Officer.
Murphy struggles with the Marines, but they control him.
What the hell....
The General wants to see you.
The two Marines begin dragging Murphy to the General's Of Murphy struggles but can't get away.
Look, there's some kind of mistake.
You're Corporal Murphy.  That's who the General wants to see.  No mistake.
The other Marine takes his side arm and all of his weapon Disarming Murphy... except for the grenades on his vest.
I need to get off the base.
I have my orders.
There are people trying to kill me.
The Officer turns to the other Marine.
He's stewed now.  Can you believe it?
What are you talking about?
Come on.  They found the smack in your bunk.  Along with some burglar tools and paraphernalia.
Closer to the General's Office.  Murphy HAS to get away.
Who is at the front gate.
I got a guy covering it for me.  So, how long you been riding the horse?
See.  No track marks on my arms...
So you shoot up between your toes.
I'm not a junkie.
That's why we have Court Martial proceedings.  So you can state your case.  Give your evidence. (beat) Though that smack kit they found in your bunk is going to...
Murphy twists right, then left, knocking the two away.  H takes off running.  Racing across the base to the front g
Murphy gets to the front gates, sees a Marine with his ba turned in the Gate Officer's kiosk and pleads his case.

This may not make any sense, but you have to help me.  There are some officers on the base who are trying to kill me.  I have to get off the base NOW.  I don't have any pass, but if you'll call General Latimer at Fort Lejuene, he can straighten this all out.  Just let me out now...
The Marine in the kiosk finally turns around: It's Rackin Rackin steps out of the kiosk.
So.  You're Latimer's snitch.  And I thought you were my friend.  All of that was bullshit, huh?
It's over, Marty.  Too much shooting.  No way to cover it all up.
I'll find away.  I'm the magic man.  It'll all disappear in the paperwork. Just like you.
Rackin pulls the M249 SAW machinegun from the counter beh him with a flourish.  Aims it at Murphy.
Say goodbye.
Rackin's finger tightens on the trigger. Murphy tackles Rackin to the ground. The gun discharges but misses, tearing the kiosk to shred
You're good Murphy.  One of you is worth as dozen Artie Hormans.

A stream of hot brass hits Murphy in the face, burning hi He screams in pain. THE TWO MEN STRUGGLE WITH THE GUN BETWEEN THEM. Rackin aims the gun at Murphy to fire again, but Murphy i on top of him before he can pull the trigger.
We would have made a great team.
Murphy grabs the gun and twists it up into the air.
But you're not much of a team player, are you?
The gun explodes between the two, sending a stream of hot lead inches between their faces.
Missed.  Wanna try again?

Rackin pushes the gun barrel around until it's aimed at Murphy's face.  His finger starts to squeeze. Murphy pushes the barrel away from him. Rackin presses the hot gun barrel into Murphy's forehead. Murphy screams as the hot barrel burns his face.
Play as a team, we can win as a team.  But you're too much of a loner.
Murphy presses the barrel towards Rackin and presses Rack trigger finger. A STREAM OF GUNFIRE misses Rackin by a hair.  Rackin laug and twists the gun back around to aim at Murphy.
You left the General's son to die.  You know how much that hurt him?
Murphy pushes up on the barrel.
Bullets and flames fill the space between the two as they continue struggling for control of the machinegun.        Each one pressing the barrel towards the other's face.
That man's like a father to me, Murphy.  When they were going to Double D me, he stood up for me.

Murphy looks down the gun barrel and sees Rackin squeezin the trigger.  He KICKS up, hitting Rackin in the groin. When Rackin doubles over in pain, Murphy twists the gun a to aim at Rackin's chest and presses his trigger finger. Click!                                                    Out of shells.
Rackin lets go of the gun, laughs.
You want the gun, take it.
You take it.

WHAM!  He slams the machinegun into Rackin's face. Rackin and Murphy wrestle to the ground, fighting hand to hand.  Rolling, gouging, head butting.  They end up at th gate, slamming against the chain link.
Hey!  What have we here?
Rackin sticks his fingers through the pins on Murphy's grenades, pulls his hand away.
With these rings, I make thee dead.

Rackin scrambles to the kiosk. Murphy looks down as the live grenades fall from his vest the pavement.  He wipes his hand across them... rolling t across the drive to the kiosk. RACKIN sees the grenades rolling at him and tries scrambl away... but is trapped in the kiosk.
Noooooooooooo!
Murphy dives behind a stone wall.

head_text.subj: THE KIOSK AND FRONT GATES EXPLODE

text: A huge fireball, raining debris down over Murphy.         Rocking the entire base with its concussion. Murphy gets to his feet, looks from the blasted open fron gate (escape) to the General's Office across the base. Makes a decision.

Newhouse is looking at the dog tag in his hand, and a fra photo of TED on the desk.  Remembering the past, and past mistakes.  His gun is on his desk. All of Murphy's belongings are stacked by the door.
Heard you wanted to see me.
Newhouse looks up.
Where's Martin?
Dead.  So're Delmar and Horman.  It's over General.
You couldn't let it go, could you? First you kill my son...
I didn't kill Ted.  You did.
Saudi Arabia. War.  The helicopter waits for Murphy and T A voice on the Officer's radio.
Cobra Zero Seven, what is your status?
Waiting at extraction point Alpha.
What your hold up?
Gunnery Sergeant Murphy asked us to wait five minutes for him.

The other side of the conversation, from a radio room set in a tent a few miles from the enemy lines.  All we see i the radio, and several other Marines (including Veillers) the background.  The "VOICE" is revealed at the scene's e
You take orders from Gunnery Sergeants, Mr. Mainwarring?
No, sir, but he said...
I give the orders.
We dolly around until we see the "VOICE"s face.
Return to base immediately.
General Newhouse lowers the mike.  Veillers tries to spea
Sir....
There is a chain of command in this service.  It is to be followed link by link.  When I give an order, it is to be carried out to the letter.  Does everyone here understand that?
Yes, sir.
Newhouse puts his hand on top of his gun, looks at Murphy
I loved the Corps so much that I gave it my only son.
He lifts the gun.                                         Murphy spots his stack of belongings by the door. On top, his Beretta 9mm automatic.
After Ted's death, I was depressed.  Thought of killing myself. (beat) Then I was transferred here.
Newhouse looks at his gun.
Met Marty.  Took him under my wing.  Thought I'd turn him into a Marine.
The gun shifts towards Murphy.
But he was wild.  Uncontrollable.
Murphy inches towards his foot locker and gun.
Called himself the magic man.  He even tricked me.  I covered up his little messes.  Running whores on the base.  Running drugs on the base. (beat) The man was like a son to me.
Newhouse shifts the gun, aiming it at himself.
It just got out of control.  There was no way to stop Rackin's crazy schemes without implicating myself.
When something is wrong, General, you fix it.  No matter the price.
It would have been the end of my career.  The end of my life.
You should have court martialed Rackin when you had the chance.  You should have done what's right.  You're what's wrong with this base, General.
Murphy grabs the phone on Newhouse's desk and dials.
General Latimer, please.
Newhouse drops his gun and hangs up the phone.
I can't let you do that.
I don't see any other choice.
I do.

Newhouse grabs his gun off the desk, twists it around to at himself, ready to commit suicide.                     Then has a better idea:  Aims at Murphy and fires. Murphy dives for his gun, grabs it, rolls to his feet. Murphy and Newhouse square off for a second like gunfight at high noon.  Aiming at each other.  Looking in each oth eyes.  Waiting for the other to move first.
Newhouse and Murphy fire at the same time.

Murphy gets hit in the shoulder, goes down. Newhouse gets hit in the chest, slams back against the wa As Newhouse lays dying on the floor his fingers reach for the dog tag on the floor a few feet away. Stretching. Getting closer. Closer. Fingers almost touching the memory of his son. Then he dies, without ever touching it. Murphy staggers to his feet, just as the MPs and Veillers storm into the General's office.
The exploded front gates.  Fires still burning. The place is a war zone.
Shots of the destruction at the base on CNN News.

Four men were killed in a daring terrorist attack on a United States Marine Base.  These are not the first Marines to die at the hands of Terrorists.  In October of 1983, two hundred and thirty seven Marines were killed in Beirut as the result of a terrorist bombing.  More recently...
THE TV STATION CLICKS TO ANOTHER CHANNEL: Same news. We see the PRESIDENT in the Rose Garden (stock footage?).

In a special memorial ceremony today in the White House Rose Garden, the President awarded medals to the brave Marines killed in the terrorist attack against Camp Richards in San Diego. (beat) The Congressional Medal Of Honor was awarded to Corporal Arthur Horman of Key Largo, Florida...
A photo of Artie Horman, as the medal is layed on top.
Sergeant David Delmar, of Phoenix City, Arizona...
Photo of Delmar as the medal is layed on top.
Gunnery Sergeant Martin L. Rackin of Detroit, Michigan...
Photo of Rackin as the medal is layed on top.
And a special Medal Of Honor to General Anthony Newhouse.
The last medal is placed on Newhouse's photo.
Murphy turns away from the cell's TV set and yells at the GUARD outside.
Hey!  Can you turn this damned TV off?
The TV screen goes dark, and Murphy sits on his bunk, loo through the bars, waiting for his court martial.
